Title:
Determining probiotic potential of cholesterol reducing
Lactobacillus and Weissella strains isolated from South Indian fermented
koozh and Gherkin (fermented cucumber).
Keywords:
Lactic acid bacteria, Gherkin, Koozh, Lactobacillus
crispatus GI9, Weissella koreensis FKI21
Abstract:
The objective of this study was to evaluate the probiotic
potential of lactic acid bacteria (LAB) isolated from traditionally
fermented South Indian koozh and fermented gherkin (cucumber) and select
candidates to be used as a potential probiotic. Fifty one LAB strains
were isolated and four strains were identified as Lactobacillus (GI6,
GI9, GI11 and GI15), three strains were identified as Weissella (FKI13,
FKI21 and FKI29) and screened for their probiotic potential. The in
vitro tests including survival in simulated acidic (pH 1.0, 2.0 and 3.0)
and bile conditions (0.30% and 0.50% w/v), antimicrobial activity
(against three gram negative, two gram positive bacteria and one yeast),
resistance to eleven antibiotics and cholesterol reducing property were
analyzed. All the Lactobacillus and Weissella strains were able to
survive in low pH and bile salt conditions at pH 3.0 and 0.30% bile salt
for 3 h while GI9 and FKI21 were able to resist pH 2.0 and 0.50% bile
salt for 3h without losing their viability. All LAB strains exhibited
inhibitory activity against tested pathogens and FKI21 showed highest
diameter mean (9.04±0.55) against gram negative bacteria. The majority
of the tested strains were resistant to gentamycin, cefuroxime,
ofloxacin and erythromycin, while sensitive to novobiocin and kanamycin.
All strains were able to deconjugate bile salts, where higher
deconjugation was observed in the presence of sodium glycocholate
(P<0.05). The strain FKI21 showed maximum autoaggregation (79%) and
coaggregation with E. coli MTCC 1089 (68%). The exopolysaccharide
production was ranged from 68.39 to 127.12 mg/L (P<0.05). Moreover,
maximum cholesterol reduction was observed in GI9 (58.08 µg/ml) and
FKI21 (56.25 µg/ml) with bile salts. Due to their probiotic potential,
the strains GI9 and FKI21 were identified by 16S rRNA sequencing and
confirmed as Lactobacillus crispatus GI9 and Weissella koreensis FKI21
and regarded as a novel probiotic. This is the first study reporting the
isolation of Weissella koreensis FKI21 from fermented koozh and
demonstrates their cholesterol reducing potential.
